'''Maurice Princet''' (1875 – October 23, 1973){{cite book |last=Miller |first=Arthur I. |authorlink=Arthur I. Miller | title=Einstein, Picasso: Space, Time, and the Beauty That Causes Havoc |year=2001 |publisher=Basic Books |location=New York |isbn=0-465-01860-2 |pages=171 }} was a [[French people|French]] [[mathematician]] and [[actuary]] who played a role in the birth of [[cubism]]. He was an associate of [[Pablo Picasso]], [[Guillaume Apollinaire]], [[Max Jacob]], [[Jean Metzinger]], and [[Marcel Duchamp]]. He is known as "le mathématicien du cubisme" ("the mathematician of cubism").{{cite book |last=Miller |title=Einstein, Picasso |pages=100 |isbn=0-465-01859-9 }} Miller cites: * {{cite book |last=Salmon |first=André |authorlink=André Salmon |title=Souvenir sans fin, Première époque (1903–1908) |year=1955 |publisher=Éditions Gallimard |location=Paris |pages=187 }} * {{cite book |last=Salmon |first=André |authorlink=André Salmon |title=Souvenir sans fin, Deuxième époque (1908–1920) |year=1956 |publisher=Éditions Gallimard |location=Paris |pages=24 }} * {{cite book |last=Crespelle |first=Jean-Paul |authorlink=Jean-Paul Crespelle |title=La Vie quotidienne à Montmartre au temps de Picasso, 1900-1910 |year=1978 |publisher=Hachette |location=Paris |pages=120 |isbn=2-01-005322-2 }}{{cite book |last=Décimo |first=Marc |title=Maurice Princet, Le Mathématicien du Cubisme |year=2007 |publisher=Éditions L'Echoppe |location=Paris |language=French |isbn=2-84068-191-9 }} [[Image:Jouffret.gif|right|thumb|An illustration from Jouffret's ''Traité élémentaire de géométrie à quatre dimensions''. The book, which influenced Picasso, was given to him by Princet.]] Princet is credited with introducing the work of [[Henri Poincaré]] and the concept of the "[[Four-dimensional space|fourth dimension]]" to the cubists at the [[Le Bateau-Lavoir|Bateau-Lavoir]].{{cite book |last=Miller |title=Einstein, Picasso |pages=101 |isbn=0-465-01859-9 }} Princet brought to Picasso's attention a book by [[Esprit Jouffret]], ''Traité élémentaire de géométrie à quatre dimensions'' (''Elementary Treatise on the Geometry of Four Dimensions'', 1903),{{cite book |last=Jouffret |first=Esprit |title=Traité élémentaire de géométrie à quatre dimensions et introduction à la géométrie à n dimensions |url=http://historical.library.cornell.edu/cgi-bin/cul.math/docviewer?did=04810001 |accessdate=2008-02-06 |year=1903 |publisher=Gauthier-Villars |location=Paris |language=French |oclc=1445172 }} a popularization of Poincaré's ''[[Science and Hypothesis]]'' in which Jouffret described [[hypercube]]s and other complex [[Polyhedron|polyhedra]] in four [[dimension]]s and projected them onto the two-dimensional page. Picasso's sketchbooks for ''[[Les Demoiselles d'Avignon]]'' illustrate Jouffret's influence on the artist's work.{{cite book |last=Miller |title=Einstein, Picasso |pages=106–117 }} In 1907, Princet's wife left him for [[André Derain]], and he drifted away from the circle of artists at the Bateau-Lavoir.{{cite book |last=Robbin |first=Tony |authorlink=Tony Robbin |title=Shadows of Reality, The Fourth Dimension in Relativity, Cubism, and Modern Thought |year=2006 |publisher=Yale University Press |location=New Haven |isbn=0-300-11039-1 |pages=34 }} But Princet remained close to Metzinger and participated in meetings of the [[Section d'Or]] in [[Puteaux]]. He gave informal lectures to the group, many of whom were passionate about mathematical order.{{cite book |last=Everdell |first=William R. |authorlink=William Everdell |title=The First Moderns: Profiles in the Origins of Twentieth-Century Thought |year=1997 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |location=Chicago |isbn=0-226-22480-5 |pages=312 }} Princet's influence on the cubists was attested to by his contemporaries. [[Maurice de Vlaminck]] wrote, "I witnessed the birth of cubism, its growth, its decline. Picasso was the obstetrician, Guillaume Apollinaire the midwife, Princet the godfather."{{cite journal |last=Vlaminck |first=Maurice |authorlink=Maurice de Vlaminck |date=June 6, 1942 |title=Opinions libres... sur la peinture |journal=Comédia |pages=1, 6 |quote=J'ai assisté à la naissance du cubisme, à sa croissance, à son déclin. Picasso en fut l'accoucheur, Guillaume Apollinaire la sage-femme, Princet le parrain. }} in {{cite book |last=Seckel |first=Hélène |editor=William Rubin, Hélène Seckel, and Judith Cousins |title=Les Demoiselles d'Avignon |year=1994 |publisher=Museum of Modern Art |location=New York |isbn=0-87070-162-2 |pages=264 |chapter=Anthology of Early Commentary on ''Les Demoiselles d'Avignon'' }} In 1910, Metzinger said of him, "[Picasso] lays out a free, mobile perspective, from which that ingenious mathematician Maurice Princet has deduced a whole geometry".{{cite journal |last=Metzinger |first=Jean |authorlink=Jean Metzinger |date=October–November 1910 |title=Note sur la peinture |journal=Pan |pages=60 }} in {{cite book |last=Miller |title=Einstein, Picasso |pages=167 }} Later, Metzinger wrote in his memoirs that:
Maurice Princet joined us often. Although quite young, thanks to his knowledge of mathematics he had an important job in an insurance company. But, beyond his profession, it was as an artist that he conceptualized mathematics, as an aesthetician that he invoked ''n''-dimensional continuums. He loved to get the artists interested in the new views on space that had been opened up by Schlegel and some others. He succeeded at that.{{cite book |last=Metzinger |first=Jean |authorlink=Jean Metzinger |title=Le cubisme était né |year=1972 |publisher=Éditions Présence |location=Paris |isbn= |pages=43–44 }} in {{cite book |last=Ferry |first=Luc |authorlink=Luc Ferry |others=Robert De Loaiza, trans. |title=Homo Aestheticus: The Invention of Taste in the Democratic Age |year=1993 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |location=Chicago |isbn=0-226-24459-8 |pages=215 }}
[[Louis Vauxcelles]] sarcastically dubbed Princet "the father of cubism":
M. Princet has studied at length non-Euclidean geometry and the theorems of Riemann, of which Gleizes and Metzinger speak rather carelessly. Now then, M. Princet one day met M. Max Jacob and confided him one or two of his discoveries relating to the fourth dimension. M. Jacob informed the ingenious M. Picasso of it, and M. Picasso saw there a possibility of new ornamental schemes. M. Picasso explained his intentions to M. Apollinaire, who hastened to write them up in formularies and codify them. The thing spread and propagated. Cubism, the child of M. Princet, was born.{{cite journal |last=Vauxcelles |first=Louis |authorlink=Louis Vauxcelles |date=December 29, 1918 |title=Le Carnet des ateliers: La Père du cubisme |journal=Le Carnet de la semaine |pages=11 }} in {{cite book |last=Henderson |first=Linda Dalrymple |title=The Fourth Dimension and Non-Euclidean Geometry in Modern Art |year=1983 |publisher=Princeton University Press |location=Princeton |isbn=0-691-10142-6 |page=72 }}
Duchamp told Pierre Cabanne, "We weren't mathematicians at all, but we really did believe in Princet".{{cite book |last=Cabanne |first=Pierre |title=Dialogues with Marcel Duchamp |year=1971 |publisher=Thames and Hudson |location=London |pages=39 }} in {{cite book |last=Crunden |first=Robert Morse |title=American Salons: Encounters with European Modernism, 1885-1917 |year=1993 |publisher=Oxford University Press |location=New York |isbn=0-19-506569-7 |pages=431 }} == See also == * [[Mathematics and art]] * [[Actuary]] ==Notes== {{Reflist|2}} ==Further reading== {{Refbegin}} * {{cite book |last=Décimo |first=Marc |title=Maurice Princet, Le Mathématicien du Cubisme |year=2007 |publisher=Éditions L'Echoppe |location=Paris |language=French |isbn=2-84068-191-9 }} * {{cite book |last=Henderson |first=Linda Dalrymple |title=The Fourth Dimension and Non-Euclidean Geometry in Modern Art |year=1983 |publisher=Princeton University Press |location=Princeton |isbn=0-691-10142-6 }} * {{cite book |last=Miller |first=Arthur I. |title=Einstein, Picasso: Space, Time, and the Beauty That Causes Havoc |year=2001 |publisher=Basic Books |location=New York |isbn=0-465-01860-2 }} {{Refend}} {{Persondata | NAME = Princet, Maurice | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = French mathematician | DATE OF BIRTH = 1875 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = October 23, 1973 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Princet, Maurice}} [[Category:French actuaries]] [[Category:Cubism]] [[Category:French art]] [[Category:French mathematicians]] [[Category:1875 births]] [[Category:1973 deaths]]
